column4: Whats the best proggy to sound edit an mp3 sound to dampen or even remove the thud thud thud of the drums?
try audacity
check out ubuntu studio, see what audio editing software is included there
it's a ubuntu version for audio and video editing
I'm not suggesting you install it.. just see what software they include
here's a list.. https://wiki.ubuntu.com/UbuntuStudio/PackageList
not to mention having a command shell which is a scripting language
well.. I don't think having a scriptable shell has some kind of magic +5 to os -knowledge perk.. but sure =)
it sort of babies you into the coding world
mm.. you could have a point there.. but this is getting offtopic
this might be worth reading http://www.ubuntu.com/community/ubuntustory/Debian
I think one the biggest differences is the release schedule when it comes to new packages and such
if an application has multiple threads I think it will be spread out.. according to the scheduler and whatnot.. I'm not sure what the difference is between "has multiple threads" and "thread aware"
I just want to be assured that I am making full use of my quad-core rather than using just 1/4th of it's processing power when I am running vbox virtual machines
oh.. I'm not sure how virtualbox handles it.. why not try it? start two vm's.. run something in both and have a look at the system monitor at the different cores
which system monitor are you referring to?
system, administration, system monitor
if you're running gnome, that is
supposing I am not running gnome and this is a remote ubuntu-server?
ah.. then the system monitor won't be there.. try running htop, it will display the cpu load for the different kernels
you can probably make top display the same thing.. but I'm to lazy to search the man page for the correct switces =)
I think pressing '1' will expand the CPUs to the total number of cores
ahh.. nice.. didn't know that one =)
